headline: Fetterman skipping U.S. Senate debate at Muhlenberg College; Lamb, Kenyatta expected to attend
author: Morning Call Staff
sentences:
“We have believed since the beginning of this campaign that voters deserve three debates that reach the most households in markets across Pennsylvania.”
Fetterman will participate in a debate April 21 at WHTM in Harrisburg, April 25 in a debate sponsored by Spotlight PA, The Philadelphia Inquirer, Trib Total Media, PennLive/The Patriot-News, and WITF at Dickinson College and a third televised debate that another TV station in Philadelphia is expected to announce soon.

Chris Borick, professor of political science and director of the Muhlenberg College Institute of Public Opinion; Jenny DeHuff, editor-in-chief, City & State PA; and Ari Mittleman, founder and host, PA Political Podcast: Pennsylvania Kitchen Table Politics will be the moderators.

The debate, hosted by City & State PA, Pennsylvania Kitchen Table Politics, the Muhlenberg College Institute of Public Opinion and the Muhlenberg College Democrats student organization, will be from 3 to 4:30 p.m. in front of a live audience at Muhlenberg College.
The Pennsylvania Democratic candidates for U.S. Senate will appear for the first time in person on the same stage on Sunday at a Muhlenberg College debate, but only two of the invitees will be there.
Fetterman’s campaign announced that the lieutenant governor has accepted invitations to participate in three televised debates ahead of the May 17 primary election.
”Debates are an important part of this primary, and I’m proud to have already committed to three,” said Fetterman in a news release.
John Fetterman will not attend the debate, according to the college, which gave him a 5 p.m. Thursday deadline.
The other two candidates, state Rep. Malcolm Kenyatta and U.S. Rep. Conor Lamb, D-17, are expected to debate.
Pennsylvania residents have been invited to submit questions for the debate via the City & State website.
Each candidate will have 90 seconds for opening remarks and 60 seconds for closing remarks.
It will take place in early May in Philadelphia, according to Fetterman’s campaign.
Moderators will include some of the submitted questions during the debate.
Candidates will have 75 seconds to respond to each question.
